university_connect.admin_views.change_leave(request, leave_id, status)[source]¶

Redirects to the change leave page

Parameters

  • request (django.http.HttpRequest) – Client request object. Comes from a HTML template or other function.

  • leave_id (int) – Primary key of the leave report in the LeaveReport table.

  • status (int) – Represents current status of leave report. 0 for pending, 1 for approved and 2 for rejected

Returns

response – Client response object. Goes to a HTML template. Context contains variables used in the frontend

Return type

django.http.HttpResponse

Bases: django.utils.deprecation.MiddlewareMixin

Middleware Class to help with user authentication

process_view(request, view_func, view_args, view_kwargs)[source]¶

Checks user sessions and makes sure users aren’t able to access views they’re not allowed to

Parameters

  • request (django.http.HttpRequest) – Client request object. Comes from a HTML template or other function.

  • view_func (Function) – View function that is being called by the current user

Returns

redirect – Redirects to the page that calls it

Return type

django.http.HttpResponseRedirect

admin¶

Accessor to the related object on the forward side of a one-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Restaurant(Model):
    place = OneToOneField(Place, related_name='restaurant')

Restaurant.place is a ForwardOneToOneDescriptor instance.

upload_url¶

The descriptor for the file attribute on the model instance. Return a FieldFile when accessed so you can write code like:

>>> from myapp.models import MyModel
>>> instance = MyModel.objects.get(pk=1)
>>> instance.file.size

Assign a file object on assignment so you can do:

>>> with open('/path/to/hello.world') as f:
...     instance.file = File(f)

attendancereport_set¶

Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a many-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Parent.children is a ReverseManyToOneDescriptor instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

    toppings = ManyToManyField(Topping, related_name='pizzas')

Pizza.toppings and Topping.pizzas are ManyToManyDescriptor instances.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

attendance_set¶

Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a many-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Parent.children is a ReverseManyToOneDescriptor instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

objects = <django.db.models.manager.Manager object>¶
profile_pic¶

The descriptor for the file attribute on the model instance. Return a FieldFile when accessed so you can write code like:

>>> from myapp.models import MyModel
>>> instance = MyModel.objects.get(pk=1)
>>> instance.file.size

Assign a file object on assignment so you can do:

>>> with open('/path/to/hello.world') as f:
...     instance.file = File(f)

university_connect.models.create_user_profile(sender, instance, created, **kwargs)[source]¶

Creates a user profile

Parameters

  • sender (BaseUser) – User creating the new profile

  • instance (BaseUser) – Data to be stored in the new user

  • created (boolean) – If true, instantiate new object of the respective user
